name: Crumpets
instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a bowl, and beat vigorously for 2 minutes. A stand or hand mixer, set on high speed, work well here.

Cover the bowl, and let the batter rest at room temperature for 1 hour. It will expand and become bubbly. Towards the end of the rest, preheat a griddle to medium-low, about 325°F. If you don't have an electric griddle, preheat a frying pan; it shouldn't be as hot as the temperature you use to cook pancakes.

Lightly grease the griddle or frying pan, and place well-greased 3 ¾-inch English muffin rings in the pan, as many as will fit. (If you don't have English muffin rings, use well-cleaned tuna cans, from which you've removed the top and bottom.) Pour sticky batter by the scant ¼-cupful into each ring; a muffin scoop works well here.

After about 4 minutes, use a pair of tongs to slip the rings off. Cook the crumpets for a total of about 10 minutes on the first side, until their tops are riddled with small bubbles/holes. They should be starting to look a bit dry around the edges. Their bottoms will be a mottled, light-golden brown. Note: They probably won't be as full of holes as store-bought crumpets; that's OK.

Turn the crumpets over, and cook for an additional 5 minutes, to finish cooking the insides and to brown the tops gently. This isn't traditional; real crumpets are white on top, but the crumpet police won't chastise you for adding a little color to the tops.

Remove the crumpets from the pan, and repeat with the remaining batter, until all the crumpets are cooked. Serve warm. Or cool completely, wrap in plastic, and store at room temperature. To enjoy, warm in the toaster. Serve with butter, or butter and jam.

name: Chocolate Sheet Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
Mix white sugar and flour in a large bowl.

Combine 1 cup melted butter, water, and 3 tablespoons cocoa powder in a small saucepan; stir over medium heat until butter is melted and mixture is well combined. Pour melted butter mixture over sugar and flour; beat well.
Beat in baking soda, ½ cup milk, eggs, and vanilla extract. Pour batter into prepared pan.
Bake in preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center of cake comes out clean, 20 to 25 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool on a wire rack.

Combine remaining ½ cup butter, 3 tablespoons cocoa powder, and milk in a small saucepan; stir over medium heat until butter is melted and mixture is well combined. Beat powdered sugar into the butter mixture, mixing until frosting is smooth. Pour over cooled cake.

name: Banana Bread
instructions: Preheat oven to 325°F, and grease a 9x5-inch loaf pan.
Mix together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a small bowl.
In another small bowl, mash the bananas. Then add milk, vanilla, and (optionally) cinnamon.
In a large bowl, beat butter until light and fluffy; then beat in the sugars. The mixture should be fluffy and consistent. Add eggs, one at a time, and beat thoroughly after adding each egg.
Stir the banana mixture into the butter mixture until combined. Next, stir in the dry mixture until thoroughly blended. At this point, you can fold in the chocolate chips, if you want them.

Pour batter into the loaf pan. Bake at 325°F about 70 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then move to wire rack to let cool completely.

name: Peanut Butter Oatmeal Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
In a large bowl, beat the chilled butter. Beat in the brown sugar, white sugar, and peanut butter until smooth.  Add the eggs, one at a time, until the mixture is smooth and consistent.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; stir this into the peanut butter mixture.
Add the oats, mixing until just combined. Drop teaspoon-sized balls of dough onto ungreased baking sheets.
Bake at 350°F for 10 to 15 minutes, or until just light brown. Cool.

name: Scones
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F. Put the butter in the freezer.
In a medium bowl, mix flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda and salt.
Using a cheese grater, grate the frozen butter into the flour mixture. Work the butter in with your fingers until the mixture resembles coarse meal.
Stir in the raisins.
In a small bowl, whisk sour cream and egg until smooth.
Using a fork, stir sour cream mixture into flour mixture until large dough clumps form. Use your hands to press the dough against the bowl into a ball.
Place on a lightly floured surface and pat into a 7- to 8-inch circle about ¾-inch thick. Sprinkle with remaining 1 tsp. of sugar.
Use a sharp knife to cut into 8 triangles; place on a cookie sheet (preferably lined with parchment paper), about 1 inch apart.
Bake until golden, about 15 to 17 minutes. Cool for 5 minutes and serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Chocolate Chip Cookies
instructions: Preheat the oven to 375°F. Lightly grease two baking sheets
Using an electric mixer, beat the butter until it is fluffy. Then, combine the sugars with the butter and beat well.
Add the salt, vanilla, vinegar, and baking soda, beating until smooth and creamy
Add in the egg and beat until smooth. Make sure to thoroughly scrape the bowl so that the entire mixture has the same consistency.
Mix in the flour, then the chocolate chips.
Scoop tablespoonful balls of dough onto the baking sheets. Leave some room on all sides of the dough, since it will spread.
Bake the cookies for 11 to 12 minutes, until edges are golden brown.

Remove the cookies from the oven, and cool on the pan until they’ve set enough to move without breaking. Once the cookies are sufficiently cool, move them to a plate or platter to finish cooling. Repeat with the remaining dough.

name: Snickerdoodles
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
In a large mixing bowl, cream butter and sugar until fluffy. Add eggs and vanilla.
Blend in flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt. Shape dough by rounded spoonfuls into balls.
In a small bowl, stir together sugar and cinnamon.
Roll the balls of dough in the sugar-cinnamon mixture. Make sure that the balls are completely covered.
Place balls on an uncreased baking sheet, about 2 inches apart.
Bake 8-12 minutes, until the cookies are well set. Let them cool on the sheet for several minutes.

name: Easy Bread
ingredients: 2 cups warm water (about 105°F, not more than 110°F)
instructions: In a large bowl, mix yeast, sugar, salt and water until the yeast is dissolved.
Gradually add the flour, one cup at a time, and mix thoroughly--the dough should begin to pull away from the sides of the bowl.
Turn the dough out onto a floured surface to knead.

To knead the dough, fold the far edge of the dough back over on itself towards you. Push the heels of your hand into the dough, and push away. After each push, rotate the dough 90°. Repeat for about 10 minutes, sprinkling only enough flour on your kneading surface to prevent sticking.
Next, grease the mixing bowl with some olive oil, butter, or non-stick spray.
Put the dough in the bowl and turn it over once to grease the top. Cover the bowl with a damp, warm towel and keep in a warm place until the dough roughly doubles in size--about 1 to 2 hours.
Punch down the dough with your fist and briefly knead out any air bubbles. Cut the dough in half and shape into two French-style loaves.
Sprinkle a baking sheet with flour or cornmeal, and place the loaves on the sheet. Let the loaves rest for 5 minutes.
Lightly slash the tops of the loaves 3 or more times diagonally and brush them with cold water.
Bake at 400°F for 35 to 45 minutes, until the loaves are golden brown. They should sound hollow when tapped.

name: Blonde Brownies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F, and grease an 8x8-inch pan
Melt butter. Remove from heat. Add brown sugar; blend well and cool.
Add egg and vanilla, and mix well.
Add the dry ingredients (flour, baking powder, and salt). Mix well.
Pour into the 8x8-inch pan and bake at 350°F for 25 minutes.

name: Brownies
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F, and lightly grease a 9x13-inch pan.
Melt the butter and, in a large bowl, combine with the sugars and vanilla.
Beat in the eggs, one at a time, and mix well after adding each egg.
In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, cocoa powder, and salt (and, optionally, the baking soda). The dry mixture should be light and airy.
Gradually stir the flour mixture into the egg mixture until blended.
Stir in the chocolate chips. Use a spoon or spatula to spread the batter into the 9x13-inch pan.
Bake at 350°F for 35-40 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick comes out clean. Allow to cool before cutting.

name: Honey Whole Wheat Bread
instructions: In a large bowl, mix together the warm water, the yeast, the salt, and the honey, until the mixture is consistent throughout.
Add in 2 cups of flour and the vegetable oil, and beat until smooth.
Stir in the remaining flour until the dough begins to leave the sides of the bowl. Dough should be soft and easy to handle.
Let the dough sit 20-30 minutes, then transfer to lightly oiled surface and knead for about 8 minutes. Dough should be supple
Transfer the dough to a greased bowl, cover with a warm, damp cloth, and let sit 1-2 hours, until puffy (dough need not necessarily be doubled in size).
Return the dough to a lightly oiled surface and shape into a loaf; place the loaf in a loaf pan and cover with greased plastic wrap.
Let rise until dough is an inch over the top of the pan in the center (about 1-2 hours). As the dough finishes rising, preheat the oven to 350°F.
Bake the bread for 30 minutes; do not overbake. If needed, tent the loaf with aluminum foil after the first 20 minutes, to prevent browning; whole wheat flour means this bread will tend to brown.
Remove from oven and let cool on a rack. If desired, rub the crust with butter to create a softer crust. Let bread cool completely before slicing.

name: Blueberry Muffins
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease muffin cups or line with muffin liners.
First, make the topping mixture: with a fork, mix together brown sugar, flour, butter, and cinnamon. Set aside.
In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, salt, and baking powder.
In a separate bowl, mix vegetable oil with the egg and milk. Stir into the flour mixture.
Fold in blueberries. Fill muffin cups about two-thirds full, and sprinkle with crumb topping mixture.
Bake for 18 to 20 minutes at 400°F, or until done.

name: Buttermilk Biscuits
instructions: Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Whisk flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar in a large bowl.
Add the chilled butter, and work it into the mixture until the whole thing resembles coarse meal.
Add the buttermilk and stir until a soft dough forms.
Scoop the dough out onto a baking sheet in ¼-cup portions.
Bake at 375°F for 25-30 minutes, until golden brown.

name: Cutout Cookies
instructions: Place butter and honey in a saucepan. Melt, stirring often.
Add sugar, bourbon, and lemon zest. Mix until sugar is melted. In a separate bowl, mix together the flour and the baking soda.
While the mixture cools, mix the dry ingredients together in a separate bowl.
Once the honey mixture is cool, add the egg. Mix. Then add the wet ingredients to the dry mixture.
Wrap with plastic wrap and chill in the fridge for 3 hours.
Preheat the oven to 300°F. Sprinkle a countertop with flour, then divide the dough into thirds and roll out the dough. Put the dough that you're not working on back into the fridge.
Cut the dough using cookie cutters or the opening of a drinking glass.
Bake at 300°F for 12 minutes, or until just browned. Let cool.

name: Biscotti
instructions: Preheat oven to 300°F. Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper.
Sift or whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl. Set aside.
Beat the butter and sugar together until just combined. Add eggs and beat. Do not overmix.
Add the flour mixture, the almonds, and the aniseed to the butter mixture until just combined.
Divide the dough in half. Lightly flour the countertop and roll each half of the dough into a log.
Put a log on each baking sheet and bake for 45 minutes. Then switch the sheets in the oven, reversing from front to back and top to bottom, and bake for another 45 minutes.
Remove from oven. While the logs are still hot, slice them into 1/2-inch wide pieces.
Line the biscotti back on the baking tray and bake for another 10 minutes. Take out and let cool on a rack.

name: Ginger Creams
instructions: Mix butter, sugar, egg, molasses, and rum.
In a separate bowl, mix together the dry ingredients.
Add the ginger, and then mix the dry ingredients together with the wet ingredients.
Cover and let chill for one hour. While the dough chills, prepare the frosting by mixing the butter, powdered sugar, and vanilla.
Heat oven to 400°F. Using a teaspoon or a small cookie scoop, drop the dough onto baking sheets lined with parchment paper.
Bake 8 minutes at 400°F, or until just set. Remove from oven and cool.

name: Lemon Ricotta Muffins
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F. Line a 12-cup muffin tin with muffin liners.
Zest and juice the large lemon. You should get about 1/4 cup of juice and 2 tablespoons of zest. Rinse and drain the raspberries
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside. Keep the flour handy; you'll need it for a later step.
In a large bowl, vigorously whisk together the ricotta cheese, sugar, honey, lemon juice, zest, eggs, oil, and milk. Fold the flour mixture into the liquid mixture until the batter is just combined.
In a small bowl, toss the raspberries with some flour. Very gently, fold the raspberries into the muffin batter.

Fill the muffin cups 3/4 full of batter. Garnish with extra raspberries, if you wish. Bake at 425°F for five minutes, then reduce the heat to 375°F and bake another 15-20 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean.
Remove the muffins from the tin and allow to cool on a wire rack. Dust with sugar, if desired.

name: Earl Grey Cookies
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Set 1 cup of butter out to soften. Take six bags of Earl Grey tea and cut them open; measure out 2 tablespoons. If you have loose leaf tea rather than bags, you may want to grind the leaves to a finer consistency.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, tea, baking powder, salt, and black pepper. Set aside.
In a mixer, whip the butter at high speed until battered, then add the sugar. Beat on high for about 2 minutes. The mixture should be light and nigh fluffy.
Add the egg and the vanilla, beating until just combined.
Slowly add the dry mixture, beating until just combined.
Scoop out tablespoon-sized balls of dough, and flatten them gently between your hands. Set them about 3 inches apart on a baking sheet.

Bake at 350°F for 13-17 minutes, depending whether you like your cookies soft and a bit doughy or firm and a bit crunchy. Either way, bake at least until set in the center. Remove the cookies from the sheet as soon as they are cool enough to do so, and put them in the fridge to cool. Cookies are best served chilled.

name: Dinner Rolls
instructions: On a stovetop, melt the butter. Heat the milk to 110°F. In a large mixing bowl, combine the milk, butter, and sugar, until sugar is dissolved.
Sprinkle the yeast on top of the warm milk mixture. Stir until the yeast is dissolved, then let sit for 5 minutes. While waiting, combine the flour and salt in a separate bowl.
In a small bowl, beat an egg. Add it to the milk mixture. Slowly mix the flour mixture into the milk mixture, until just combined. Remove from bowl and knead for 5 to 10 minutes.
Grease a large bowl and place the dough inside. Cover with a cloth and put in a warm place. Let the dough rise for an hour; it should roughly double in size.
Grease a 9x13-inch pan. Punch the dough down and knead it again. Divide into 24 equally-sized balls, and place in the pan. Cover again and let rise for 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 375°F.
In a small bowl, beat the egg. Brush onto the the tops of the rolls. Sprinkle with salt. Bake at 375°F for 24 minutes, until golden brown and cooked through.
Remove. Serve while warm, or cool before storing.

name: Flourless Chocolate Cookies
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper, or grease well. These cookies will stick if you're not careful.
In a large bowl, combine the powdered sugar, the cocoa powder, and the salt.
Separate the eggs and keep the whites, in a smaller bowl. Add vanilla.
Stir the egg white mixture into the cocoa mixture until consistent. The combination really should resemble cookie dough. Next, beat in the chocolate chips.
Place the dough on the baking sheets in tablespoon-sized scoops and let bake at 350°F, 10 to 12 minutes. The cookies should be set.
Let the cookies cool on the sheets for 5 or 10 minutes before you remove them to a cooling rack. Do not try to take the cookies off the sheets right away--this is guaranteed to result in disaster.
